questions.text: The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Epididymis:

Explanation:

  • The marked structures in the histological image are cilia.
  • Cilia are slender, hair-like structures found on the surface of many epithelial cells.
  • They play a vital role in the movement of fluids and particles along various passageways in the body.
  • While the epithelial lining of the epididymis does have stereocilia (long microvilli), it does not typically have cilia.

Surface Projections

  • Microvilli: Small finger-like projections (~1 micrometer) that increase surface area, found in the brush border of the kidney, gall bladder, and intestinal cells.
  • Stereocilia: Long microvilli (15-20 micrometers) located in the hair cells of the inner ear and the epididymis in the male reproductive tract.
  • Cilia:
    • Motile cilia (7-10 micrometers) propel substances along the surface of certain epithelia.
    • Non-motile cilia, present on nearly every cell in the G0 stage, were once considered nonfunctional but are now known to play a role in signaling pathways during both development and adulthood.

 

Oviduct, Bronchi, Ependyma (Options A, C, and D): have cilia in their epithelial lining.

questions.text: A patient presents with carcinoma near anal opening. Which of the following lymph node is most likely involved first?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Superficial inguinal lymph node

Explanation:

  • Since the carcinoma is located near the anal opening—referring to the perianal skin or anal verge, which lies below the pectinate line—it primarily drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Features

Upper Anal Canal

Lower Anal Canal

Development

Endodermal

Ectodermal

Epithelium

Simple columnar

Stratified squamous

Nerve supply

Autonomic nerves

  • Painless
  • Sympathetic (L1, L2)
  • Parasympathetic (S2, S3, S4)

Somatic nerves

  • Painful
  • Sympathetic (S2, S, S4)

Arterial supply

Superior rectal artery

Inferior rectal artery

Venous drainage

Superior rectal vein draining into the portal system

Inferior rectal vein draining into caval system

Lymphatic system

Internal iliac nodes

(Option D ruled out)

Superficial inguinal nodes

(Option A)

Common type of haemorrhoids

Internal haemorrhoids

External haemorrhoids

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Deep inguinal lymph node receive lymph from the superficial inguinal nodes and are involved later, not as the first site of drainage from the anal verge.

Option C: Paraaortic lymph node drains lymph from deep abdominal and pelvic organs like the testes and ovaries, not from the anal region.

questions.text: Match the following

choices.text: A- prostate, B- ureter, C- vas deferens , D- seminal vesicle
A- vas deferens, B- ureter, C- prostate , D- seminal vesicle
A- ureter, B-prostate, C- vas deferens , D- seminal vesicle
A- vas deferens, B- ureter, C-prostate , D- seminal vesicle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: A- prostate, B- ureter, C- vas deferens , D- seminal vesicle

Explanation

  1. Sperm travels from the epididymis through the vas deferens.
  2. The vas deferens joins with the seminal vesicle to form the ejaculatory duct.
  3. The ejaculatory duct then passes through the prostate gland, where the sperm mixes with fluids from the seminal vesicles and the prostate.
  4. This mixture, now called semen, is then expelled into the urethra and out of the body during ejaculation.

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted (red) in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

Option A: a. Pudendal nerve: The pudendal nerve is the correct option. The pudendal nerve is a nerve that arises from the sacral plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineum, including the external genitalia and the anus. The ischial spine is an important landmark in the pelvis, and the pudendal nerve passes posterior to the ischial spine during its course.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is an incorrect option. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and arises from the sacral plexus. It runs down the posterior thigh and does not directly pass through or relate to the ischial spine.

Option C: Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve is an incorrect option. The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial compartment of the thigh. It does not have a direct relationship with the ischial spine.

Option D: Femoral nerve: Option D is not explained in the initial question. However, the femoral nerve is an incorrect option. The femoral nerve arises from the lumbar plexus and provides sensory and motor innervation to the anterior thigh. It does not have a direct relationship with the ischial spine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the levator ani muscles is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 

Option D: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscles is that they are attached to the pelvic brim. The levator ani muscles are not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, they originate from various bony structures in the pelvis, including the pubis, ischial spine, and tendinous arch of the pelvic fascia. The muscles then converge and attach to the coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: The statement that the levator ani muscles support pelvic viscera is correct. The levator ani muscles form a muscular sling within the pelvis and provide support to the pelvic organs, including the bladder, uterus, and rectum.

Option B: The statement that the levator ani muscles converge downwards and medially is correct. The muscle fibers of the levator ani muscles come together and run in a downward and medial direction towards the midline of the pelvis.

Option C: The statement that the levator ani muscles consist of the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles is correct. The levator ani muscles are composed of three main parts: the pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis muscles. The iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles are two of the components of the levator ani muscle group.

questions.text: Bleeding vessel in hemorrhoids is?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Superior rectal vein: Hemorrhoids are swollen and inflamed blood vessels in the rectum and anus. The bleeding associated with hemorrhoids usually occurs from the engorged veins. The superior rectal vein, which drains blood from the rectum, is often involved in hemorrhoidal bleeding. Thus, the superior rectal vein (option B) is the correct answer.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is responsible for supplying arterial blood to the rectum. However, in the context of hemorrhoids, the bleeding vessel is typically a vein rather than an artery. Therefore, the superior rectal artery (option A) is not the correct answer.

Option C: Middle rectal artery: The middle rectal artery is responsible for supplying blood to the middle portion of the rectum. While it plays a role in rectal blood supply, it is not typically associated with bleeding in hemorrhoids. Therefore, the middle rectal artery (option C) is not the correct choice.

Option D; Middle rectal vein: The middle rectal vein drains blood from the middle portion of the rectum. Similar to the middle rectal artery, it is not directly associated with hemorrhoidal bleeding. Hence, the middle rectal vein (option D) is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Which lobe of the prostate is responsible for the formation of the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Median lobe: The median lobe of the prostate is the correct answer. It is a small, middle portion of the prostate that projects into the bladder and forms the uvula vesicae. The uvula vesicae is a smooth, rounded elevation located in the internal base of the bladder.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the prostate does not specifically form the uvula vesicae. The anterior lobe is a small part of the prostate that lies in front of the urethra, but it does not contribute to the formation of the uvula vesicae.

Option B: Posterior lobe: The posterior lobe of the prostate also does not form the uvula vesicae. The posterior lobe is the largest part of the prostate and it surrounds the ejaculatory ducts, but it is not directly involved in the formation of the uvula vesicae.

Option D: Lateral lobes: The lateral lobes of the prostate do not form the uvula vesicae. They are the largest and most prominent parts of the prostate gland that are located on either side of the urethra, but they do not contribute to the formation of the uvula vesicae.

questions.text: Inguinal ligament is formed due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - External oblique aponeurosis:

  • The inguinal ligament is indeed formed by the lower free border of the external oblique aponeurosis. It runs from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) to the pubic tubercle, providing support to the inguinal region.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Internal oblique aponeurosis: While the internal oblique contributes to the inguinal canal, it's not directly responsible for the formation of the inguinal ligament.

Option C - Transversalis fascia: The transversalis fascia is involved in the formation of the deep inguinal ring, but it does not contribute to the inguinal ligament.

Option D - Inguinal muscle: There isn't a specific muscle referred to as the "inguinal muscle" that forms the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is formed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Transversalis fascia:

  • The deep inguinal ring is formed by an opening in the transversalis fascia. It's a passage through which structures like the spermatic cord (in males) or the round ligament of the uterus (in females) pass.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Internal oblique aponeurosis: This contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, not the deep inguinal ring.

Option B - External oblique aponeurosis: Similar to the internal oblique, the external oblique contributes to the formation of the superficial inguinal ring, not the deep inguinal ring.

Option D - Transversus abdominis: The fibers of the transversus abdominis contribute to the formation of the transversalis fascia, indirectly playing a role in the creation of the deep inguinal ring.

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except:
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D.

  • This is the correct answer. The 2nd palmar interossei muscle does not form the marked structure. The palmar interossei muscles are located in the palm of the hand and are responsible for adduction of the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion on the dorsal side of the fingers.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. The 2nd dorsal interossei muscle is involved in forming the marked structure. The dorsal digital expansion is formed by the dorsal interossei muscles, which are located between the metacarpal bones of the hand. They extend from the metacarpal bones to the extensor expansions on the dorsal side of the fingers.

Option B. The lumbricals extensor digitorum muscles are involved in forming the marked structure. The lumbrical muscles arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and pass through the dorsal digital expansion. They contribute to the extension of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints.

Option C. The extensor digitorum muscle is involved in forming the marked structure. The extensor digitorum muscle is located on the dorsal side of the forearm and gives rise to the tendons that insert into the dorsal digital expansions. It is responsible for the extension of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, and distal interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: The below image is of a femur bone. Which muscles are attached to "A"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Iliopsoas

Explanation:

  • The A point marked on the image of the femur is the lesser trochanter of the femur.
  • The Iliopsoas muscle arises from the Iliac fossa and lumbar spine and attaches to the lesser trochanter of the femur.
  • Iliopsoas is a large compound muscle of the inner hip composed of the iliacus and psoas major muscles. It is situated on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • The iliopsoas muscle is the primary flexor of the hip joint. It is also responsible for external hip rotation at the hip joint.
  • It causes flexion of the trunk at the hip, lateral flexion of the trunk (psoas major only)

Incorrect Options:

Gluteus maximus (Option A):

  • is the largest and heaviest muscle in the body.
  • It takes its origin from the dorsum of the hip bone as well as from the dorsum of the sacrum and also has ligaments.
  • Insertion is on the gluteal tuberosity on the posterior aspect of the upper femur bone.

Quadriceps femoris (Option C):

  • are the group of muscles in front of the thigh. Quadriceps perform a variety of movements, including running, jumping, kicking, and walking.
  • There are 4 Quadriceps:
    • Rectus femoris.
    • Vastus lateralis
    • Vastus medialis
    • Vastus intermedius.
  • When Quadriceps muscles contract, they extend the knee joint, straightening the leg.
  • The quadriceps femoris attaches to the patella via the quadriceps tendon and does not attach to the lesser trochanter, so this is incorrect.

Adductor Magnus (Option D):

  • is a prime mover of the femur into adduction. One portion of the adductor muscle flexes the thigh and works as a medial rotator; the other extends the thigh and is a lateral rotator.
  • The adductor magnus attaches to the adductor tubercle on the femur, not the lesser trochanter, so this is also incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Foramen rotundum

Explanation:

Foramen Rotundum. The foramen rotundum is indeed located in the sphenoid bone of the skull. It is a rounded opening that lies in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, on the medial part of the infratemporal surface. The foramen rotundum serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (V2), which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).

cranial fossa" data-author="" data-hash="12243" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="300" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/McWHT5lBdfvkRHJJ0vie1746530429.png" width="300" />

 

Foramen of Middle Cranial Fossa

Structures Passing through

Foramen Rotundum

Maxillary Nerve

 

Foramen Ovale

  • Mandibular nerve

  • Accessory meningeal artery

  • Lesser petrosal nerve

  • Emissary vein

  • Occasionally, the Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Foramen Spinosum

  • Middle meningeal artery and vein,

  • Emissary vein

  • Nervus spinosus(Meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)

Foramen Lacerum

A triangular opening at the base of the skull, but in living individuals, it is filled with cartilage, and no major structures pass through it.

  • Foramen lacerum contributed by 3 bones-temporal, occipital and sphenoid

  • The internal carotid artery and nerve plexus traverse its superior end;

  • The nerve to the pterygoid canal passes through its anterior wall.

  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery and an emissary vein pass through it.

Foramen Ovale (Option B): The foramen ovale is a separate opening in the sphenoid bone, located posterior and slightly lateral to the foramen rotundum. It is larger and oval-shaped.

Vidian Canal (Option C): The vidian canal, or pterygoid canal, is a narrow bony passage in the sphenoid bone. It runs obliquely between the pterygopalatine fossa and the middle cranial fossa.

Foramen Spinosum (Option D): The foramen spinosum, a small opening, is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, positioned posteriorly and laterally to the foramen ovale.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flexion and external rotation.

Explanation:

  • The muscle attached to the area marked in the given image is the iliopsoas
  • It is the largest and strongest inner hip thigh muscle and is primarily responsible for flexion and external rotation of the thigh at the hip joint.

Iliopsoas: is the chief flexor at the hip joint, assisted by sartious and pectineus as the accessory muscles

 

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: During walking, the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gluteus medius

 

Explanation:

  • The gluteus medius is the primary muscle responsible for hip abduction and stabilization of the pelvis during walking.
  • During the stance phase, when one leg is on the ground and the other is lifted, the gluteus medius of the supporting leg contracts to prevent pelvic drop on the opposite side.
  • This mechanism is known as the Trendelenburg mechanism, and dysfunction leads to a Trendelenburg gait.

Gluteus Medius and Hip Stability

Feature

Description

Origin

Ilium (between anterior and posterior gluteal lines)

Insertion

Greater trochanter of femur

Innervation

Superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1)

Function

Hip abduction, pelvic stabilization during gait

Clinical Relevance

Weakness leads to Trendelenburg sign/gait, seen in superior gluteal nerve injury

 

Action of the Hip joint, corresponding muscles and their innervation:

 

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply


 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)
 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)


 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Pectineus

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)
 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)





 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

 

Gluteus maximus (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily functions in hip extension (e.g., rising from a seated position) rather than stabilizing the pelvis.

Obturator internus (Option C): Incorrect because it mainly functions as a lateral rotator of the hip, not in pelvic stabilization.

Quadratus femoris (Option D): Incorrect because it is a lateral rotator of the hip, not involved in abduction or pelvic stability.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the given picture.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1

Explanation:

  • The pelvic diaphragm forms the muscular floor of the pelvis and provides support to pelvic organs. It primarily consists of the levator ani (pubococcygeus, puborectalis, iliococcygeus) and coccygeus muscles. The marked Option 1 correctly identifies the pelvic diaphragm.

Pelvic Diaphragm

Feature

Details

Components
  • Levator ani (pubococcygeus, puborectalis, iliococcygeus)
  • Coccygeus

Function
  • Supports pelvic organs
  • Aids in defecation, urination, and childbirth
  • Maintains continence

Openings
  • Urogenital hiatus (for urethra and vagina)
  • Anal hiatus (for rectum)

Clinical Relevance
  • Pelvic organ prolapse if weak
  • Urinary/fecal incontinence
  • Perineal tears in childbirth

 

2 (Option B): Incorrect – This marks the external anal sphincter, a voluntary muscle involved in anal continence but not part of the pelvic diaphragm.

3 (Option C): Incorrect – This marks the internal anal sphincter, an involuntary muscle that controls defecation, unrelated to the pelvic diaphragm.

4 (Option D): Incorrect – This marks the pudendal canal (Alcock’s canal), which transmits the pudendal nerve and vessels, but does not contribute to the pelvic diaphragm.

questions.text: In the scenario of a man who fell into a manhole and sustained perineal injury, leading to difficulty in urination and presence of blood at the urethral tip, a diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was determined. In this particular case, where would the urine accumulation be the least expected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The medial portion of the thigh

Explanation:

  • In bulbar urethral injury, the spongy urethra is damaged, leading to extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal space.
  • Urine can track into the perineum, scrotum, penis, and anterior abdominal wall due to the continuity of the Colles' fascia, Dartos fascia, and Scarpa's fascia.
  • However, it does not spread into the thigh because Colles' fascia is firmly attached to the fascia lata of the thigh, preventing urine from tracking into the medial thigh.

Urine Extravasation in Urethral Injuries

Type of Urethral Injury

Common Cause

Urine Accumulation

Areas Restricted

Bulbar urethral injury (Spongy urethra rupture)

Straddle injury (e.g., falling on a hard object)

Perineum, scrotum, penis, anterior abdominal wall

Thigh (due to attachment of Colles' fascia)

Membranous urethral injury

Pelvic fractures

Retropubic space, perineum

Scrotum and penis (if Buck’s fascia remains intact)

Penile urethral injury

Blunt trauma or catheterization

Confined within Buck’s fascia if intact, or perineum if ruptured

None if Buck’s fascia is disrupted

Perineum (Option A): incorrect because urine accumulates in the superficial perineal space due to the injury.

Anterior abdominal wall (Option B): incorrect because urine can track upward via Scarpa’s fascia.

Root of the scrotum (Option D): incorrect because urine spreads into the scrotum via continuity with Dartos fascia.

questions.text: A woman delivered a healthy baby and to control her postpartum hemorrhage an artery was ligated. Then later she developed pain under her gluteus muscle. Which was the artery ligated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Internal iliac artery

Explanation:

In cases of severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), ligation of the internal iliac artery is a common life-saving procedure. However, this artery also supplies the gluteal region via the superior and inferior gluteal arteries. Ligation can lead to ischemia and pain in the gluteal region, which explains the symptoms seen in this patient.

Internal Iliac Artery and Its Branches

Artery

Origin

Major Branches

Supply

Clinical Significance

Internal Iliac Artery

Common iliac artery

Anterior and posterior divisions

Pelvic organs, gluteal region, perineum

Ligation used in PPH management

Uterine Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Anastomoses with ovarian artery

Uterus, cervix, vagina

Commonly ligated in hysterectomy

Superior Gluteal Artery

Posterior division of internal iliac

Branches to gluteal muscles

Gluteus medius, minimus, and tensor fascia lata

Injury can cause Trendelenburg gait

Inferior Gluteal Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Supplies deeper gluteal structures

Gluteus maximus, sciatic nerve

Injury affects hip extension

 

Uterine artery (Option A): incorrect because it primarily supplies the uterus and is ligated in hysterectomy or uterine artery embolization, but does not directly cause gluteal pain.

Superior gluteal artery (Option B): incorrect because while it supplies the gluteal muscles, it is a branch of the internal iliac artery and is not directly ligated in PPH.

Inferior gluteal artery (Option C): incorrect because, though it supplies the gluteal region, it is also a branch of the internal iliac artery and is rarely ligated alone.

questions.text: The rupture of the penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Ischiorectal fossa

 

Explanation:

The rupture of the penile urethra does NOT cause extravasation of blood into the ischiorectal fossa because this area is located deep to the perineal membrane and is separated from the superficial perineal structures by the deep perineal fascia.

 

Pathway of Urine Extravasation in Penile Urethral Rupture:

If the spongy (penile) urethra ruptures, urine and blood extravasate into the:

  1. Superficial perineal pouch → Because the Buck’s fascia (deep fascia of the penis) is torn.
  2. Skin around the scrotum → Due to continuity of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles’ fascia).
  3. Anterior abdominal wall → Through the continuity of Scarpa’s fascia (superficial fascia of the lower abdomen) with Colles' fascia.

 

Urethral injury causes

Anterior urethra

Meatus

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, hypospadias, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus)

Pendulous urethra

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, hypospadias, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus), sexually transmitted infections, crush injury

Bulbar urethra

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus), sexually transmitted infections, crush injury, straddle-type injury

 

Urethral injury causes

Posterior urethra

Membranous urethra

Instrumentation, pelvic fracture with urethral distraction defects

Prostatic urethra

Instrumentation, radiation therapy for prostate cancer (external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy)

Bladder neck

Instrumentation, radiation therapy for prostate cancer (external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy)

 

Superficial perineal pouch (option A): Rupture of the penile urethra with Buck’s fascia tear directly leads to urine extravasation here.

 

Anterior abdominal wall (option B): Colles' fascia (superficial perineal fascia) is continuous with Scarpa's fascia, allowing urine and blood to spread upward into the anterior abdominal wall.

 

Skin around the scrotum (option D): Urine spreads into the scrotal skin because the superficial perineal fascia (Colles’ fascia) extends over the scrotum.

questions.text:
Which muscles are responsible for constituting the pelvic diaphragm?

A. Iliococcygeus

B. Pubococcygeus

C. Obturator internus

D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Answer: A) A and B

 

Explanation:

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular structure that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It is composed of the levator ani muscles and the coccygeus muscle.

  • Iliococcygeus (Muscle A) → Part of the levator ani, helps support pelvic organs.
  • Pubococcygeus (Muscle B) → Another part of the levator ani, important for continence and pelvic floor integrity.

The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular sheet that forms the inferior border of the pelvic cavity. It consists of several muscles that work together to support the pelvic organs and assist in various functions.

The components of the pelvic diaphragm are:

  • Levator ani muscle complex, which includes:
    • Pubococcygeus
    • Iliococcygeus
  • Coccygeus muscle or Ischiococcygeus

Functions:

  • Supports pelvic viscera (bladder, uterus, rectum).
  • Maintains urinary and faecal continence.

Innervation: Primarily by the pudendal nerve (S2-S4).

Clinical significance:

  • Weakness can lead to prolapse and incontinence.
  • Kegel exercises can improve function.

Obturator internus (Muscle C) – Incorrect: This muscle is part of the lateral pelvic wall, not the pelvic diaphragm. It assists in hip rotation, not pelvic floor support.

 

Deep transverse perinei (Muscle D) – Incorrect: This muscle is part of the urogenital diaphragm, which lies inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It supports the perineal body but does not constitute the pelvic diaphragm.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in healthy adult males?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) 20cc

Explanation:

The normal volume of the prostate in a healthy adult male is approximately 20–30 cc (cubic centimeters or mL).

 

The prostate gland grows gradually with age, and an enlarged prostate (>30 cc) is often seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Measurement of prostate volume is commonly done using transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) or MRI.

 

The prostate gland weighs 20 gm in a normal adult male and is made up following zones:

 

Zone

Features

Peripheral
  • This zone makes up about 70% of the prostate gland and surrounds the urethra.
  • The majority of prostate cancers (70-80%) originate in the peripheral zone, since it is rich in glandular tissue, making it susceptible.

Central
  • It is situated at the base of the prostate gland, surrounding the ejaculatory ducts.
  • Inflammation of the prostate gland (prostatitis) commonly affects the central zone.

Transitional
  • It is located near the urethra and accounts for about 5-10% of the prostate gland.
  • BPH primarily affects the transitional zone, leading to urinary symptoms such as frequency, urgency, weak urine flow, and difficulty initiating or stopping urination.

 

 

50cc (option B): A prostate volume of >30 cc is usually indicative of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

 

 

75cc (option C): A prostate volume of >40–50 cc is considered moderately enlarged, often seen in symptomatic BPH.

 

 

100cc (option D): Prostates exceeding 100 cc are considered severely enlarged, often leading to significant urinary obstruction and requiring medical or surgical intervention.

questions.text: A person who had a road traffic accident presented to ER with injury to bulbar urethra. What can be the location of collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Anterior abdominal wall

Explanation:

  • The bulbar urethra is a part of the male urethra located just before the penile urethra. An injury to the bulbar urethra can lead to a urethral rupture, allowing urine to leak into the surrounding tissues. In the case of bulbar urethral rupture, the urine extravasates to
    • Superficial perineal pouch
    • Scrotum
    • Penile region
    • Anterior abdominal wall

Extravasation of Urine:

  • Due to rupture of spongy urethra below the perineal membrane causes urine to accumulate in – superficial extravasation.
    • If Buck's fascia is intact, extravasation of blood and urine confined to penile shaft.
    • If Buck's fascia is disrupted:
      • Superficial perineal pouch
      • Scrotum
      • Around penis
      • Lower part of anterior abdominal wall
  • Urine cannot escape to:
    • Deep perineal pouch (because of perineal membrane)
    • Ischiorectal fossa (because of Colles' fascia)
    • Thigh (fascia lata)
  • Due to rupture of membranous urethra above the perineal membrane causes urine to accumulate in – deep extravasation.
    • Deep perineal pouch
    • Extraperitoneal space
    • Space of Retzius (space around bladder and prostate)
    • Superficial perineal space if perineal membrane also ruptured

 

Inguinal pouch (Option A): The inguinal pouch is not a typical location for urine collection. It is an area in the groin region, and urine collection there wouldn't be directly related to a bulbar urethral injury.

Peritoneal cavity (Option B): The peritoneal cavity is the abdominal cavity where various organs are located. It is not a common location for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. Leakage of urine into the peritoneal cavity could result in a condition known as urinoma, but this is not the primary location of urine collection in cases of bulbar urethral injury.

Ischiorectal fossa (Option C): The ischiorectal fossa is situated in the pelvic region, but it is not a usual site for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. This fossa contains fat and connective tissue and is not directly connected to the urinary system.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of blood in her stools. Physical exam reveals firm, enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. A contrast CT scan is performed and a possibly cancerous mass is visualized in the lower part of the gastrointestinal tract. In which location is the mass most likely located?

choices.text: Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

Explanation:

  • Lymphatic drainage from this region primarily goes to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
  • A cancerous mass in this location would lead to enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes, as seen in this patient.

Distal rectum (Option B): This option is incorrect as lymph from the inferior part of the anal canal drains to the superficial inguinal nodes.

Sigmoid colon (Option C): This option is incorrect as sigmoid colon lymph nodes drain to the inferior mesenteric nodes.

Proximal rectum (Option D): This option is incorrect as the proximal rectum drains to the sacral nodes.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level shown by the blue line in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - L4-L5 

  • If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L2-L3: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

Option C - L5-S1: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

Option D - L3-L4: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A person who had a road traffic accident presented to ER with injury to bulbar urethra. What can be the location of collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anterior abdominal wall

  • The correct answer. The bulbar urethra is a part of the male urethra located just before the penile urethra. An injury to the bulbar urethra can lead to a urethral rupture, allowing urine to leak into the surrounding tissues. In the case of bulbar urethral rupture, the urine extravasates to
    • Superficial perineal pouch
    • Scrotum
    • Penile region
    • Anterior abdominal wall

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inguinal pouch: The inguinal pouch is not a typical location for urine collection. It is an area in the groin region, and urine collection there wouldn't be directly related to a bulbar urethral injury.

Option B - Peritoneal cavity: The peritoneal cavity is the abdominal cavity where various organs are located. It is not a common location for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. Leakage of urine into the peritoneal cavity could result in a condition known as urinoma, but this is not the primary location of urine collection in cases of bulbar urethral injury.

Option C - Ischiorectal fossa: The ischiorectal fossa is situated in the pelvic region, but it is not a usual site for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. This fossa contains fat and connective tissue and is not directly connected to the urinary system.

questions.text: The ischial spine corresponds to which level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tip of the coccyx:

  • The ischial spine refers to the sharp bony prominence which protrudes from the posterior margin of the ischium. It separates the greater sciatic notch above from the lesser sciatic notch below.
  • Despite commonly being referenced in relation to the S3-S5 vertebral level in some anatomical texts, in certain contexts or specific anatomical references, it may be aligned or associated with the tip of the coccyx.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of  Option B

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the image given.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pouch of Douglas
 

Explanation:

 

  • The marked area in the image is the Pouch of Douglas.
  • The Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch, is the lowest point of the peritoneal cavity in females.
  • It is located between the posterior aspect of the uterus and the anterior aspect of the rectum.
  • It is a common site for the accumulation of fluids, such as in the case of peritoneal infections or blood after pelvic surgeries.

 

Rectouterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas):

  • Pouch between rectum posteriorly and uterus anteriorly
  • Most dependent part of the abdominal cavity in standing
  • Most dependent part of the abdomen in the lying down position is the hepatorenal pouch of Morrison

 

Morrison's pouch (Option A): This is the space between the liver and the right kidney. It is not located in the pelvic area but in the upper abdomen.


 

Vesicouterine pouch (Option B): This is located between the uterus and the bladder, higher in the pelvic cavity, and is not the same as the Pouch of Douglas.

Ischioanal Fossa (Option D) is a fat-filled space situated on either side of the anus, located just below the pelvic diaphragm, essentially acting as a cushion around the anal canal; it is considered part of the anal region and is sometimes referred to as the ischiorectal fossa.
